thread.title: Andy Rihs, hearing-aid billionaire and passionate cyclist, dies at 75

title: Andy Rihs, hearing-aid billionaire and passionate cyclist, dies at 75
text:
April 19, 2018 / 11:04 AM / Updated 29 minutes ago Andy Rihs, hearing-aid billionaire and passionate cyclist, dies at 75 Reuters Staff 3 Min Read 
ZURICH (Reuters) - Andreas “Andy” Rihs, a Swiss billionaire whose success with the world’s largest hearing aid company Sonova financed his passion for professional bicycle racing and soccer, has died at the age of 75. FILE PHOTO: BMC Racing Team's owner Andy Rihs of Switzerland speaks during the cycling team's official presentation in Nazareth, near Ghent January 11, 2013. REUTERS/Francois Lenoir/File Photo 
Rihs, who died on Wednesday and had been suffering from cancer, was in the early 2000s the face of Switzerland’s Phonak Cycling Team, named after his hearing aid brand. 
He was also owner of Swiss bicycle maker BMC, which has a professional team, and Bern’s Young Boys soccer team. 
With Phonak, Rihs experienced pro cycling’s highs and lows, when top U.S. rider Floyd Landis won the 2006 Tour de France before testing positive for a banned substance. Another Phonak rider, American Tyler Hamilton, was stripped of his 2004 Olympic gold medal as a drug cheat. 
“As a passionate cyclist, I am bitterly disappointed that the sport of cycling apparently has become a synonym for doping,” Rihs said in 2006 when he disbanded the Phonak team. 
Still, Rihs, a hobby rider who himself climbed France’s famed 1,912 metre Mont Ventoux, stuck to the sport, giving millions of francs to build an 8,000-square-metre velodrome in Switzerland that caters to Swiss Olympic athletes. FILE PHOTO: BMC Racing Team's Cadel Evans of Australia (L), wearing the leader's yellow jersey, celebrates on the Champs Elysees next to Andy Rihs, co-owner of the BMC team, after he won the 98th Tour de France cycling race in Paris July 24, 2011. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo 
Australian Cadel Evans won the 2011 Tour de France riding for Rihs’ BMC team, a victory that still stands. 
“A great supporter of sport has left us,” the team said on Thursday. 
Rihs, born in 1942 in Stuttgart, Germany, took over his father’s Swiss hearing aid company in 1966 with a partner and later his brother, helping grow sales to nearly 2.4 billion Swiss francs (1.75 billion pounds) in 2017. Rihs owned about 3.6 percent of Sonova stock, but left its board several years ago. 
“We have not only lost a great friend with tremendous foresight and an extraordinarily creative spirit, but also a multitalented and passionate entrepreneur,” Sonova Chairman Robert Spoerry said. 
Rihs also loved soccer. His Young Boys team in the Swiss capital of Bern this year leads the top division, ahead of perennial favourite FC Basel by 11 points with just six games left. 
“Andy, thanks for everything,” the team said on Twitter. “You’ll be missed.” Reporting by John Miller; Editing by Richard Balmforth
